text:
Although it's not something I can see myself doing I do have some sympathy for <@UPMUFSGCR>'s approach in this sort of scenario where you're potentially risking a large portion of your float, simply because that's stressful and I can see that there's some value in limiting that anxiety that you might be willing to sacrifice a bit of gain for.

When you're rinsing through horse races every few minutes you're usually not risking that much and you can ride out any volatility in just a few days, but lumping a large percentage of your money on an outright punt which doesn't come around that often is far scarier. In the former case you're a fool if you hedge, but in the latter I can see why you might. In the end money's only useful if it's making your life better, so yeah - why not sacrifice a little to buy a better night's sleep.

Although I never hedge I do keep significantly more float in my accounts than is necessary. That's not optimal, I should have that money invested and working for me, but it means I never have to stress about volatility so I take the hit. Same thing really.
